1120451014728015872.text: Of course the financial loss of a breach far exceeds the cost the security tooling in the SDLC. Risk reduction is why we should recommend doing so, and not because bugs/vuln are X-times cheaper to fix earlier. /6

1120450821685239808.text: It'll likely cost more in tooling to proactively prevent vulns in Prod, but it’s also the wrong answer because it's the wrong question. An Eng manager, of any reasonably sized team, will not be attracted by ANY idea that only saves $80,000 (less than the cost of 1-FTE). /5

1120450741683073030.text: Alternatively, let's say the business invests in whatever SDLC tools and processes are necessary to ensure those vulns never make it to production in the first place. Will that investment cost more or less than $80,000? /4

1120450682987978752.text: The average website may have around ~20 individual vulns reported annually. Therefor the total cost to fix ALL these vulns, at the most expensive stage (Prod), is $80,000 ($4,000 x 20) / 3

1120450602633519105.text: Let's assume fixing the average [website] vuln (SQLi, XSS, etc) requires ~40 man-hours to prioritize developer time, create a patch, QA/regression test, and finally push to production. At $100hr, the cost to fix each vuln in prod is $4,000. /2

1120450470349168640.text: While various research suggest that software bugs are ~5-10x less expensive to fix during the SDLC than waiting till production, this financial analysis should NOT be used as justifiction to find-fix vulnerabilities earlier. /1

1111690126109732865.text: Of course the number of devices, and the software within, in all our lives is constantly increasing. So the amount of time and energy required to keep up on software patches will eventually reach a breaking point. Never a day goes by where you don’t have to patch something.

1111689155820453889.text: This time metric is extremely important to keep track, because organizations are only capable of patching so fast. If an ORG legitimately needs days-weeks to fully patch, but adversaries begin exploiting newly published vulns is minutes-hours — there’s a big problem.

1088163689708941312.text: No question, browser extensions do some nasty and invasive things that put people's security and privacy at risk. Curtailing and  better controlling browser extension permissions makes complete sense! Their alternate business upside is getting their arms ad-blocking.

1088162825338445825.text: Google is a master strategist in this way. They find an important problem to focus on, and solving it in such a way that it also addresses a risk to their business core business.

1088162278447316992.text: So, Google must craft changes where third-party ad blockers will still limp along, preventing people from switching browsers, and not let them too badly impact it’s core business. Security and privacy issues, which are real, are a great way to execute on that.

1088161625297702913.text: With respect to ad blocking, Google must carefully balance their changes to Chrome. Ideally they’re business interests would prefer all ads be blocked, except for theirs. But, if they had a direct hand in that — gotta know the anti-trust lawsuits would closely follow.

1088160331677917184.text:
Increasing the speed of a Web by focusing on the Web browser is an excellent way to do all of that. 

Owning the browser also puts Google in a position to collect more user data, prevent competitors from doing so, and protect their ad business from third-party ad blockers.

1088159572466913281.text: IMHO, Google is an advertising platform. I say that because they make the vast majority of their money by delivering ads — on the Web. It’s in their best interest for more people to use the Web, for the Web to go FAST, as that benefits their ad delivery business.

1088159037550522368.text:
Developing a Web browser and successfully bringing it to market is an incredibly difficult and expensive business venture. 

For Google (and Chrome), the question is, why are they making that investment? What’s their upside? 

For shareholder value, there must be an answer.

1085579525805682689.text: I found a way to create recall scrolls where players could buy them from in by thousand, even tens of thousands. A week worth. Now, normally when items are purchased in bulk, general economic theory says the unit price should fall. But that’s not happened here. /3

1085579367177048064.text: The challenge players had was that while recall scrolls weren’t expensive individually, they were difficult to buy in sufficient quantities for more than a days worth (~100). So players spent a lot of their game time running around to different merchants. /2

1081263789704499200.text: Also, like the TV cable operators of yesterday, the [browser] platform owners (Google, Microsoft) don’t seem to want to enable support for ala cart and ad free content purchases as it's contrary to their business model and interests. /5

1081263768594669568.text: Today, 'Internet' content is where 'TV' content was a 10+ years ago. People want an easy way to buy content ala cart and ad free, but the window (web browser) in which they consume it doesn't technology support it. /4

1081263741302321152.text: Then the Internet came along, and with it Netflix, iTunes, Prime Video, etc emerged. The Internet made it technologically possible to buy content ala cart and ad free, which is basically how everyone does it today — a shift from paid-for by ads to direct buy. /3

1050823053221842944.text: And remember, it’s NOT ‘your data’, it’s ‘their data,’ and they can basically do with it as they wish whenever they want.

1050822349841260544.text: If you ask advertising platforms if they sell ‘your’ data, they’ll say they don’t, which is technically true. 1049742995887513600.text: What’s the logic end to this Bloomberg/Super Micro story? Does reporting eventually just stop and everyone looses interest before anyone really knows anything?

1049698374734102529.text: And then when you make the mental connection that many people tend not read anything more about a story than the headline, which effectively becomes the content, that’s where many can’t help but go back to the headline debate. Rinse. Repeat.

1049697537886539776.text: Remember that every word in every headline is carefully scrutinized and crafted to maximize views and advertising dollars. Story accuracy may come further down in the content.

1049697288350654464.text: Should a headline have used the word ‘breach’? Or ‘exposure’? Or ‘vulnerability’? etc. This is semantic debate is a red herring and not the result of laziness or a lack of understanding.
